race.name: CIRREM
race.tagline: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel in rural Roubaix.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat, wind, and humidity possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling northern Illinois farmland. Moderate elevation with farmland scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Illinois event. Rolling farmland terrain with rural location and limited organization.

biased_opinion.summary: CIRREM is a regional event in rural Roubaix, northern Illinois. The rolling farmland terrain offers moderate climbing with farmland scenery, but the rural location, limited amenities, and moderate organization keep it firmly in Tier 3. Roubaix is a small town with limited lodging and dining. It's a solid regional event for Illinois cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Illinois gravel race with rolling farmland terrain. Worth it for Illinois cyclists seeking a local event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Rural rolling Illinois farmland gravel in Roubaix.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Illinois and want a local rolling gravel event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Midwest events: Gravel Worlds, Almanzo 100, Dirty Kanza. For similar regional events: other Illinois gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Roubaix has very limited lodging. Princeton or Peru have more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel with moderate climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel in rural Roubaix.

non_negotiables.why: Rolling Illinois terrain requires sustained effort.
Illinois spring/fall means heat and wind are possible.
Rural location requires self-sufficiency and preparation.

topics.heat: Racing in Illinois heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Rolling Illinois farmland gravel in rural Roubaix.

logistics.explanation: Registration opens 9pm November 27th and "will fill up in a few minutes" for 500 spots maximum. Race day runs breakfast at 8AM, check-in until 9:45AM, 10AM start at Cumming Tap. The self-supported format means minimal race infrastructure beyond the halfway checkpoint with food and drink.

length.explanation: The 100k distance produces finish times from Dillon McNeill's 3:06:38 record down to 6+ hour survivors. Recent Masters winner Ross Eoriatti finished in 4:14:50 with tight gaps behind him. In 2025's thawing gravel conditions, that translates to plenty of suffering without excessive dark-hours grinding. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Post-race scene puts it: "Please stay around afterwards and have a good time at the Tap as long as you like. The Tap is pretty awesome, and it's in Cumming, for crying out loud."

technicality.explanation: Madison County's winding hills include bridges with "spaces between the boards that eat wheels for lunch—seriously, a friend separated his shoulder last weekend on it." The 5000+ feet of climbing comes via grinding rollers rather than technical descents, though conditions create handling challenges when gravel turns to "peanut-buttery build up." Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Over 5000 feet of climbing across 63 miles through Madison County's rolling terrain. The race organizers describe it as "winding hills" that test persistence rather than explosive power. It's Iowa elevation—death by a thousand papercuts rather than mountain passes. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 42°F and lows of 24°F, with a 41% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 26 mph. Late February timing delivers everything from 2019's "foggy with periods of rain turning to snow late, low 30's" to 2022's "4 inches of snow two days prior." Race organizer remembers "stopping several times to wring the water out of my mittens" and riders with "bright-red gloveless hands." It's winter warfare, not marketing copy. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Cumming, Iowa sits at corn-growing elevation—essentially sea level for racing purposes. The thin air you'll experience comes from 30-degree temperatures hitting your lungs, not altitude. Any breathing difficulty stems from frozen February conditions, not oxygen deprivation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Frozen gravel through Madison County in February conditions offers adventure, but it's more 'survive the elements' than 'explore the unknown.' The self-supported format and open roads add real risk—organizers explicitly warn about slippery conditions and high speeds with car traffic. It's adventure through attrition rather than exotic terrain.

prestige.explanation: Sixteen years deep, CIRREM bills itself as "the OG of winter gravel races" with enough reputation to sell out in minutes. Dave Mable's singlespeed race report earned coverage in CX Magazine. But this remains Iowa grassroots racing where winners ride "singlespeed mountain bikes, fender'ed cross bikes" rather than pro pelotons.

race_quality.explanation: This is self-supported racing with open roads and a checkpoint roughly in the middle—bare bones organization that puts the burden on you. Winners finish around 4 hours while others suffer for 6+ hours on frozen gravel through Madison County's winding hills. The pile-up among leaders in slippery conditions shows what happens when winter racing meets minimal course management.

experience.explanation: Starts and finishes at Cumming Tap, which immediately tells you this isn't some sanitized corporate event. Two inches of overnight snow followed by race-day sleet in 20-degree temps—that's the authentic winter gravel experience most races only pretend to offer. You'll remember every frozen mile of those 64 miles through Madison County.

community.explanation: The equipment list—"mountain bikes, cross bikes, ss's, fenders, fixies, fat bikes and even road bikes"—shows this crowd prioritizes showing up over showing off. Post-race hangs at Cumming Tap with awards "a few hours after winners come in, but still before everyone is off course." The organizer's advice: "ride with a buddy if you think you'll be out there a while."

field_depth.explanation: Men's Masters category saw 18% DNF rate in 2025 with tight racing—8-minute gap from first to third. Winners have emerged from singlespeeds and fender'ed cross bikes, indicating more heart than horsepower. Categories include tandem and fat bike divisions, suggesting inclusive rather than elite competitive depth. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Race morning schedule puts it: "8:00AM – Breakfast, 8-9:45AM – Rider check-in, 10:00AM – CIRREM begins, 3:00PM – Awards"

value.explanation: Registration includes 8AM breakfast, halfway checkpoint food, post-race lunch, and finishing at a tap house in Cumming, Iowa. The format strips away unnecessary support to focus spending on the experience itself. No prize purse data available, but you're paying for winter suffering and community, not payouts.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Cumming, Iowa doesn't command destination race pricing for lodging and meals. Nearest major airport likely Des Moines, about 40 miles out, keeping travel costs reasonable. The race's "absolutely no transfers and no refunds" policy and minute-long sellout suggest pricing hits the sweet spot for committed winter racers. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.
